media:group.media:title: Including assets
media:group.media:description: With this lesson, you will: describe how to enqueue styles and scripts, include CSS in your theme either using stylesheets or inline styles, include JavaScript in your theme by either using an external file or inline JavaScript, include images in your theme, and include fonts in your theme. --- View this video and others on WordPress.TV: https://wordpress.tv/2024/07/17/including-assets/

media:group.media:title: Custom functionality
media:group.media:description: This lesson dives into the theme’s functions file (functions.php) and how you can use it to add your own functionality to a theme. With this lesson, you will: describe the purpose of a WordPress theme's functions.php file, decide when to use a plugin instead of the functions.php file when developing a theme, and list some common uses of the functions.php file for extending the functionality of WordPress. --- View this video and others on WordPress.TV: https://wordpress.tv/2024/07/17/custom-functionality/

media:group.media:title: Updating your theme
media:group.media:description:
Once your theme is live on the WordPress.org theme directory, you may need to update it from time to time. This could be to fix bugs, add new features, or generally improve it.
There are two ways to update your theme on WordPress.org, uploading a new zip file, or using Subversion (SVN).
Let's look at both methods. --- View this video and others on WordPress.TV: https://wordpress.tv/2024/07/17/updating-your-theme/

media:group.media:title: Submitting your theme to WordPress.org
media:group.media:description:
When you've made sure your theme includes all the required files, passes the theme review guidelines, and you've thoroughly tested your theme, you're ready to submit your theme to the WordPress.org theme directory.
Let's dive into what this process looks like. --- View this video and others on WordPress.TV: https://wordpress.tv/2024/07/17/submitting-your-theme-to-wordpress-org/

media:group.media:title: Preparing your theme for submission
media:group.media:description:
Once you have finished developing your theme, you need to prepare it for submission to the WordPress.org theme repository.
In this lesson, you'll learn how to prepare your theme for submission, including how to test your theme, check and follow the theme review guidelines, and prepare documentation for your theme. --- View this video and others on WordPress.TV: https://wordpress.tv/2024/07/17/preparing-your-theme-for-submission/

media:group.media:title: Required theme files
media:group.media:description:
When you submit your theme to the WordPress.org theme directory, there are a set of required theme files that you need to include in your theme.
Let's look at what these files are, and why they are important. --- View this video and others on WordPress.TV: https://wordpress.tv/2024/07/17/required-theme-files/

media:group.media:title: The WordPress org theme directory
media:group.media:description:
Once you’ve developed your theme, you’re probably going to look at ways to publish it, so that WordPress users can install and use it.
One of the most popular ways to do this is to submit your theme to the WordPress.org theme directory.
Let’s dive into what the WordPress.org theme directory is, why you might consider publishing your theme there, and learn about the process of submitting your theme to the theme directory.
View this lesson and others in this course at Learn WordPress: https://wordpress.tv/2024/07/17/the-wordpress-org-theme-directory/

media:group.media:title: Exploring WordPress 6.6
media:group.media:description:
Check out some of the new features that have landed with WordPress 6.6. --- View this video and others at learn.wordpress.org.

Presenter: Wes Theron

entry.title: Adding custom user roles using a WordPress plugin

media:group.media:title: Adding custom user roles using a WordPress plugin
media:group.media:description:
Learn how to create custom user roles using a WordPress plugin to define specific responsibilities and permissions, segment users for tailored experiences, manage content moderation effectively, and establish custom workflows. --- View this video and others at www.learn.wordpress.org.
00:00 Introduction 00:22 Custom roles 1:08 Using a plugin 2:08 Granting permissions 3:26 Assigning a role
Presenter: Wes Theron

media:group.media:title: Template parts
media:group.media:description: We will explore how to create and add template parts to your theme. With this lesson, you will: describe template parts and how they work, define template part areas, and add template parts to your theme. --- View this video and others on WordPress.TV: https://wordpress.tv/2024/07/08/template-parts/

media:group.media:title: Template hierarchy
media:group.media:description: We will take a deep dive into the details of how WordPress loads templates in a browser. With this lesson, you will: explain how WordPress uses the query string, briefly explain the template hierarchy diagram, and describe the template hierarchy for a given page being queried. --- View this video and others on WordPress.TV: https://wordpress.tv/2024/07/08/template-hierarchy/

media:group.media:title: An overview of Templates
media:group.media:description: We will cover the purpose, structure and loading of templates. With this lesson you will: describe the purpose and structure of a template, list the sequence templates are loaded by WordPress, and with theme starter files in place, create a template from scratch. --- View this video and others on WordPress.TV: https://wordpress.tv/2024/07/08/templates-overview/

entry.title: WordPress.org plugin repository, a year in review

media:group.media:title: WordPress.org plugin repository, a year in review
media:group.media:description:
Get to know what features the WordPress.org repository provides to the community, how the review team is working to make plugin reviews faster and more accurate – with the aim of improving plugin compliance, reliability and security, whilst reducing plugins review backlog.
If you ever planned to work on your own plugin or already have one ready for publishing, you’ll get some best practice tips on how to improve it and get it approved quickly.

entry.title: Replacing Regular Expressions with WordPress’ new tag manipulation APIs

media:group.media:title: Replacing Regular Expressions with WordPress’ new tag manipulation APIs
media:group.media:description:
Do you hate writing Regular Expressions to parse HTML?
Do you understand why this is generally a bad idea?!
There’s new API’s available in WordPress to help you achieve your tasks without writing any REGEX.
This lightning talk will introduce you to these API’s and provide real world examples of how you might use these to simplify and stabilise your codebases.

entry.title: Legacy to Block: an indepth look at migrating a legacy website to Gutenberg

media:group.media:title: Legacy to Block: an indepth look at migrating a legacy website to Gutenberg
media:group.media:description:
Join us on a reflective journey as we share the nuances of a successful migration, from a legacy Content Management System (CMS) to WordPress, enhanced by Gutenberg and custom blocks.
This narrative unveils the different approaches we considered, shedding light on the diverse strategies that seamlessly transitioned us from the old to the new.
We will share the issues we faced, the decisions we had to embrace, and the challenges of such a complex project, in a way everyone can benefit from.
